For example, you mentioned the best of, worst of, is there anyway to classify buckets, because it's a large amount. Secondly, if we look at the future, do we have to assume that the running rates in equity revenues would be lower because you are taking less risk, how should we look at that? That's the question. Thank you.

First of all, we don't disclose that, but you have to come back to the slide, I mention you see the dividend swap, for example, it was a shock, really a shock because we were in the all the market we're in the process of the fact that the dividend will be higher and higher each year and then we have a shock because we see that not only the 2009 dividend in the market I don't what will the be the future but also 2010, 2011 and after will be sharply down and so I don't know the answer but in our mark-to-market position today it's much lower, so we can anticipate it will not reproduce in our – this was a large shock. I will not quantify but I will qualify.

Then we have faced a huge, huge volatility in the market. We have mentioned euro stock but if you see the same situation in weeks, the S&P 50 you see it was primer especially in October and in November. I think it's unsustainable to see such volatility. I should note the situation is very difficult to manage the delta, which is simple in an illiquid market with such a volatility. We don't anticipate that the weeks will stay a long time at 80%, so the weeks was at 80%, now it's back to I don't know, 50% coming from 25. So today we are not in the situation of anticipating 80% on the long time. But perhaps we will stay at 40% or 50%.

Globally, we had a shock also in what we call the volatility of the volatility, and we call that vulgar. And so this was really a big shock, we don't anticipate lots of new shock of that, but naturally we look at them. So, globally, the volatility, the volatility of volatility and that the real change is the anticipation of dividend, what was the main driver, were the main drivers and naturally on top of that the totally illiquidity of the market with the fact that there were no more hedge funds. And now we know the situation and so that we don't sell any more 'worst of' and 'best of' and a lot of things like that.

I will not quantify exactly but you see the illiquidity of the market is very interesting, we have experienced the same globally and not especially us, as a market. It means the illiquidity of the market since the beginning of December, if you remember, between the 10 years, I am thinking of interest rates, the curve, the yield term between on the 10 years and the 30 years it was, there were commented move with a lot of the illiquidity. So, we have to look at that, okay, we were not especially concerned by that but there are a lot of liquidity in the market. So we work with thinking of totally illiquidity in the market in all the underlying global entities.

Yes, I come back to that question. I think that 2007, 2006 and 2007 were very good productivity and equity during that period. And so we don't anticipate for 2009 and for 2010 is too long the same level of activities not necessarily due to us but also due to a lot of our clients because some of our clients, either of the clients globally of the market, either have disappeared, some of them disappeared.

And others have let's say are less ambitious in terms of type of product. So globally yes we don't anticipate – we anticipate probably to be at a lower level in equity derivative than we were in 2007 probably. But on the other hand a lot of actors have disappeared and we see that there is a confrontation with actors who have good signature because the clients are looking also to the counter party risk of the counter party. We are AA, as Baudouin probably mentioned 6 bank which are AA or more, not a lot of them are working in derivatives. So we see clearly in fixed income a huge change in equity, today it's too early for me to answer to that question because a lot of clients they do nothing now they do really nothing but anticipate and we see the first move, that they will comeback because you see today they have nothing in short-term interest rates. So they look at bonds. And then, probability we will come back somewhere into '09 in equity I don't know when.

So for me it's difficult to fix a level. We have anticipated lower level of revenues. We are acting to decrease the cost basis clearly and then we will see together what will the asset manager will ask him, but today it's a little too early to answer that question.

Robin Down from HSBC. Apologies to come back to the Ukraine, I appreciate it's not a huge part of your business, but as analysts we want to fill all the numbers in the spreadsheet. Two quick questions on the Ukraine, last time I looked at the exit bank accounts, it looked like you had about two-thirds of your lending and foreign exchange lending. Can you confirm whether or not that's you only lending to customers who have got foreign exchange earnings or are in fact lending to customers on a sort of under-hedged basis.

The second peculiarity with exit bank, is that it seems to get a majority of its funding from an inter bank line from BNP. So I was just wondering if you could tell us what the current inter bank exposure there is to exit bank.

And then just finally on a completely unrelated issue, the new preference shares to be issued by the government. There's huge confusion in the market and I would include myself in that group of confused people about the loss absorption characteristic of these preference shares. And I thought perhaps the easiest way to sort of get clarity on this would be to look back and say well if those preference shares have been issued on the 1st of October 2008 with your short 1.4 billion of losses and say 10% of your capital base then would be in preference shares. Would a 140 million of your losses in effect have been written down against the preference shares with the other 90% against your equity or not?
Okay, maybe if you, you can answer straight to the preference shares question and then...
We had a specific slide on the pref shares, maybe we could put, in the appendix, this could be – could be put on the screen.
What's the number?
Well, I don't know, it's one of the last one, I guess,
Yes, it's there....
Okay. And so it's an....
Instrument.

It's an instrument, which has been, created by law in France, so it's relatively new law. So it's a new instrument and you'll have to, you all need to understand that, it's not an hybrid product, it's really equity. And in terms of loss absorption, there is no difference between such a pref share and an ordinary share, it's exactly the same, meaning that they are going to be issued at let's say, I don't know 25, well the average of the 30 days, exactly the same price than the ordinary share, with the same nominal value, €2, the same premium, so the difference between the 25 and 2, let's say 23 which is given to the reserves. And then it's exactly the same than ordinary shares. So, if the bank – I hope it will not be the case but if we are losing money and losing and losing, the loss absorption is going to be exactly the same as if we had increased the capital reserve in ordinary share, exactly the same.

So, there is no difference to that respect. The difference comes from the fact that there is no voting right and clearly there is no subscription right, no intervention. I mean, so they are non-voting shares and there is a preferential dividend to the extent that the dividend is slightly higher than the ordinary dividend. So, it's a formula, 105% at the beginning and then, progressively with time it goes up to 135%. Plus in terms of yield, there is a floor and a cap on the yield.

And so, it means that there may be no dividend at all, of course, if there is no dividend they don't get any dividend either. If there is a dividend, for example, this year €1, while if we had already those shares we would have to pay a minimum, which is something like 8% times 25, which is something like €2, to those shares instead of one. There is a dilution effect because they are shares, at the end. There is some kind of dilution and especially in bad times, I would say there is some dilution. In good times, the dilution is capped by the fact and in the end it's much less because there is no upside, after a certain point, there is no upside. If we pay and if we come back to paying dividends above 5 or €6, then it will be capped at around €4 for those shares. So there is a cap, there is a floor in the share no-voting rights and that's all. And there is loss absorption exactly like a normal share.

Which is I think – what is very important is – this is the reason why the French regulator takes it fully as core equity because it is core equity and I think it's very important to understand that my understanding is this is very different from a lot of preference shares in the U.S.. So it's the same name and it's not the same product and this is – this new class – this new product which by the way it was voted by parliament in France not in relation to the government
program it is – it actually has existed now for a year...
For one year.

For one year yes and so it's new and it has been used for the second branch of the government program but actually it was voted as preference shares and the law and in parliament was voted out of the context of the state program- of the government program.

So for the Ukrainian bank when we are talking of corporate turns most often they have revenues derivative on equity in odd currencies. So that the risk situation derives more from the downturn in the economic situation and when we are talking of private individuals like the ones who directly or indirectly have revenues in odd currencies they are just two-thirds of revenues in local currency. And these customers are hit by the – and have to support the full effect of the FX change rate. This is basically the situation in Ukraine. I don't know if we disclosed the figure about the subordinated loans we have between BNP Paribas and – okay.
BNP Paribas basically I mean, it's internal funding.

No. I mean no, UkrSibbank is the consolidated – full consolidation, so what you see in the balance sheet is not the inter banking, not the intra group funding, but what you see in the balance sheet is the loans granted by UkrSibbank through – due to its claim.

I think BNP, business bank loan from BNP, so that's designed for about 12 billion Ukrainian hryvnias at the end of '07. My concern is that the basic credit loss amounts to a point where in effect you can't recover that inter-bank, intra group funding.

And again it's part of the Group and so it the – there is no point of recouping the loans we are granting. You know it's like BNL or any other subsidiary of BNP Paribas, it's part of the Group. So, of course, we have a centralized spending in the treasury and is more generated asset that we can manage with BNP Paribas. It comes what I see integrated and of course, it's subsidiary is not, while the funding of each subsidiary is completely managed and...
So, if we count upstream cash from one of the local subsidiaries, having the better option over half to HSBC and then in the fact you incur a loss?
If we incur a loss it will come from the losses incurred by the subsidiary vis-a-vis their clients.
Okay.

If – the subsidiary is in trouble it will be because they are not – they have loan losses for example and then it will be reflected in the account at this level, but not at the intra group funding level...
Maybe you can continue on the private discussion because we have now to move in the essence of time to our questions. So, please move on...
We now taking three questions from the conference.
Thank you. We now take three questions from the conference room. Please go ahead.

Good evening. I have four questions. First, regarding the preferred shares you mentioned that for the time being the yield is below the cost of capital. But, with a ceiling at 16 it would be much – much above the cost of capital. So, what could be the – consider exit of those preferred shares once they have played their – I would say interim role in the capital. Have you an idea of how you could replace that with core capital? And my second question is about the tax rate, it seems that Q4 losses has been extremely tax efficient if I may say. Could you guide us about the sort of tax level we should consider for – for '09? And the last point, I would appreciate it if we could have a breakdown of the crisis impact on the three different business line of the CIB?

Well, first, concerning the exit of one of the preferred share, I think it's a little early because we have not given, yet issued those shares so, I think it's a little bit early to think of redeeming them. And nevertheless you are right to the extent that yes, the ceiling is relatively well; it's really well, not very high, but relatively high. And we, well if there is an exit mechanism, which is the right to redeem those shares like by the way you have the right to redeem any ordinary share as well on the market. The only difference being that there is also the mechanism of flow and ceiling on the buyback price, because they are not going to be listed, so there is a mechanism which is explaining the same side. So, you have a way at any time if you want to and if you are allowed by the regulator to redeem those shares. But I think it's a little early to speak of that kind of thing. It's just the flexibility which does exist and that's it.

And in terms of tax rate, yes, we – what happened, I mean we were faced in the fourth quarter with something which is extremely rare and I hope and unpleasant and I think remained one-time and which is – we were in losses. So, yes, the tax aspects of that are very different from situations where you are making money everywhere, which used to be the case in the recent past. And what happened in fact is that we incurred the main losses in countries where the tax rate is high, namely the U.S., the U.K. and Japan and to contrary we had what decent result and profit in countries where the tax rate is very low like the Gulf countries, Luxembourg and a few other countries like that.

And so, we – the result is that we got more for – we got more if you take the whole year in fact, for all those countries above from France and Italy where we had no more results and we had no more tax rate. But all the countries above France and Italy, the non-domestic countries, the net result is very low, the net gain before tax is very low. And it's a mix of losses with high tax deferred – deferred tax asset and profit with low taxes. And the result is the kind of negative level of tax for those countries, which I agree is very unusual and – but this is the point of question we feel which explains a very lower tax rate.

In terms of guidance, we in normal years, I mean in years where we make money normally, you can keep the formal guidance which is that the tax rate in the region of 27% as the kind of land of the countries where we are operating. But the gain this year is exceptional.
Okay.

Your other question concerning cost of crisis, first of all we don't disclose business plan by business plan, but I would like to come back on my previous answer. The cost of crisis is the difference between the fact that the level of CIB as Baudouin mentioned we had a positive net income of €1.5 billion in the first quarter of 2007 and in the first quarter of 2008, it was a minus 1.5 or minus the same magnitude. Because for me it's impossible to say, okay we have just one off – outside this one off it is very exciting, because we see as I mentioned that there are clearly some one off than we will never see I think made of some counter-party risk which has materialized.

Monolines, you asked a question of monolines, I think, we – this I am surely is now over, but we will see probably more risk – credit risk and it is probably cost of crisis also. So, I think we don't know this gross specific cost of risk, because it's very difficult to assess that.
We now move to Mamoun Tazi with MF Global. Please go ahead.

Yes, good afternoon. I have three questions if I may. One is a clarification about the situation with the pref shares, and then I'll start with that one. My understanding was that the pref share will only see losses after you deplete all your retained earning. So, in that case they are not at the same level of shareholders equity. So, if you can please clarify that. The second question is about Ukraine. Is there a level at which you'll be ready to walk away from your investment in UkrSibbank, because you've invested about 200 million or there about, we don't know the exact number because you didn't disclose it. But if the losses start to mount and because you have – you are also funding the portfolio, would you – would there be a point where you just say, enough is enough, let's just cut the losses and move on?

And the third question is about CIB. You've had massive losses with regards to high volatility and heightened volatility in your equity diversified portfolio. Now assuming that things stabilize the way they are currently. Where would those – those losses be for the next couple of quarters? I know that you probably will be winding down some of the positions and therefore you might see further losses, but we don't have a sense as to what they could be going forward assuming everything is to remain stable? Thank you very much.

On the first question, yes, I mean when you issue ordinary shares, what happens? It happens that the ordinary shares are issued with a premium and the nominal value is €2 at BNP Paribas, and you issue the shares according to the market price, let's say 25, and so you issue shares at 25, and you have 23 of premium, okay and two of nominal value. And now once you have done that, if you suffer losses, yes, the losses are first denting the retained earning and only at the end they are denting the nominal value of the shares, but the first reserves including the retained earnings are first dented. And to a certain extent we can say that by paying the premium, the new shareholders have kind of both shares in the retained earnings, that's the way it works. As far as the preferred shares, it's exactly the same. There is no difference.

Yes, on Ukraine, what – it's a very long-term investment. It's a key bank in Ukraine. It's a very nice operation. They are doing a really nice job. Obviously this country is badly hit by the crisis, but obviously there will be a life after the crisis. So we do not even imagine – think to walk out of this market. So a very long-term investment and most probably in the end we will have more of this bank than less of this bank, it is the story for Ukraine.

Concerning equity derivative, first of all, I don't know what is exactly stabilized conditions, because I am sure it will not be completely stabilized because we have not only volatility, we have a lot of parameters to look. What is clear is that we have reduced in large magnitude our let's say type of primary position. I mentioned specifically let's say the dividend exposure, the dividend exposure has been reduced a lot and will continue naturally to be reduced by let's say duration because the 209 dividend will be completely known at the end of next week. So, globally not completely, but mainly.

So globally, we are in the process to see that shock in our revenues, in equity derivative, will not occur anymore. Then, what will be the level of the revenues in equity derivatives? It's difficult because we have to not only to see the volatility today, today volatility we have to see what will be the anticipated volatility. For example, at the end of March then at the end of June because we have to mark-to-market naturally all our positions. But all in all, when we are expecting that CIB has posted good results in January, that seems – as we see that the in itself is over, and we see in February and March and I don't want to anticipate anything for March, because for me I'm not stupid.

That's fine, but I mean, assuming that for example remains at the level of where it is right now, 46% or 45, would you be seeing losses from unwinding your positions in the equity derivatives portfolio?

As of today, as I mentioned, between the first quarter and today, which is January and mid February, we have paid now to close, it's also what we call toxical position, so globally perhaps there will be another huge illiquidity in the market I don't know, but if not we are now in good shape.
The last question.
We've got one more.
Okay.
Our last question comes from Guillaume Tiberghien with Credit Suisse. Please go ahead.

Yes, hi. Actually I've got two questions, if I may. The first one relates to the cost base in the corporate and investment banking, and I understand that a) you haven't paid a lot of bonuses, but you have also deferred quite a lot of the compensation into following quarters and next year. So, I would like to understand whether even those deferred costs have been accrued already in your P&L or not or whether we will see them maybe in Q1 or in Q2?

And the second questions relate to the Corporate Center, where you had obviously 400 million impairment in your equity portfolio, which is in line with the reported revenues of the Corporate Center, but you also had about 300 million of gain on your own debt, which obviously, we don't see here, so does it mean that your funding cost has gone up by 300 million per quarter or is that a wrong way to look at it? Thank you.

For the first question, we are naturally past of deferred compensation, but first of all it's deferred on the long period . And second, the large part of it is conditional, so for at least profit sharing, so in fact I don't know exactly how it will be treated by the Basel accounting. But globally, naturally, we will see something not specifically in Q1, but in Q1, Q2, Q3, Q4, but I don't know how we will be treated, the conditional impact of that aspect. So, globally it will not impact a lot, lets say, the situation of CIB, but I don't know exactly it's a good time to execute it.
Yes. Again, yes, that part of my – some kind of benefits have been given on the conditional basis of several years.
Three years.

Three years and so there are vesting conditions, which has to be met before they are actually paid. And as such, I mean, the cost is going to be spread out over the period, which and of course we'll take into account the achievement or not of the condition. So, and the total amount, the total maximum possible amount is not that huge, it is, so in terms of burden that was paid for the next two quarters is not going to be a significant investment.

And in terms of the Corporate Center, yes, the – while your calculation is a little bit rough, but it's clear that the cost of liquidity has increased quite hugely. In fact, in the fourth quarter mainly due to the fact that while all our subordinated and senior debt is swapped, again, you have about three months and so we suffered a lot from the widening of the – three month is a spread – it's three months bar spreads and especially in euro and especially euro dollar spread and which widened a lot in the fourth quarter, so it's probably not 300 million, it will be less than that, but that is – it's a big amount, probably in the region of 200.
Well, thank you very much, and thank you very much for your questions and bye-bye.
